p: However, biparental inbreeding typically incurs a fitness cost in the form of reduced viability or fecundity (biparental inbreeding depression; Nason and Ellstrand 1995; Wagenius et al. 2010). For SC to be an evolutionarily stable strategy, this cost typically needs to be less than half the fitness of outcrossed individuals (Lande and Schemske 1985). In many highly outcrossing species, the fitness cost may be such that inbreeding is not a viable option, as the population cannot persist long enough to sufficiently purge deleterious alleles.
